revision.text:
{{Infobox military unit |unit_name= 771 Naval Air Squadron |image=771NAS Crest.png |image_size=150 |caption= |dates= 1939–1955
1961–1964
1967–2016 |country= {{UK}} |allegiance= |branch= [[Fleet Air Arm]] of the [[Royal Navy]] |type= |role=[[Search and Rescue]]
Training |equipment= [[Westland Sea King|Sea King HAR.5]] |size= |command_structure= |Commanding_Officer= [[Commander]] M Shepherd [[Royal Navy]] |garrison= [[RNAS Culdrose (HMS Seahawk)|RNAS Culdrose]] |ceremonial_chief= |colonel_of_the_regiment= |nickname= |patron= |motto= "[[Non Nobis Solum]]"
([[Latin]]: "Not unto us alone") |colors= |march= |mascot= |battle_honours= |notable_commanders= |anniversaries= }} '''771 Naval Air Squadron''' of the [[Fleet Air Arm]] was formed on 24 May 1939 at [[RNAS Lee-on-Solent (HMS Daedalus)|Lee-on-Solent]] as a Fleet Requirements Unit with 14 [[Fairey Swordfish]] TSR biplanes. The Squadron carried out various exercises with ships and provided towed targets for naval air gunners and was decommissioned on 22 March 2016. [[File:RN Helicopter Pilot.jpg|thumb]] ==Second World War== The Squadron initially had a northern element (X Flight), and a southern element (Y Flight). 'X' Flight broke away on 28 September 1939 to become [[772 Naval Air Squadron]]. The reshaped 771 NAS was based at [[RNAS Hatston]] flying a variety of fixed-wing aircraft, ranging from [[Supermarine Walrus]]es to [[Hawker Hurricane]]s, from airfields across the UK and abroad. A notable point in 771s wartime history was that they started the chain that led to the sinking of the [[German battleship Bismarck]]. The Commanding Officer of [[RNAS Hatston|HMS Sparrowhawk]], Capt [[Henry Lockhart St John Fancourt, RN]], had been ordered to identify and sink the Bismarck at the earliest opportunity. The two squadrons of [[Fairey Albacore|Albacore TSR]]s he had did not have sufficient range to attack the battleship whilst in harbour. He was relying on the [[Royal Air Force]] to carry out flights over [[Bergen]], and inform the [[Royal Navy]] when the Battleship had left port. On 22 May 1941 RAF [[Coastal Command]] deemed the weather unsuitable for flight; however, Capt Fancourt, RN volunteered to put together a crew to fly 771s [[Martin Maryland]] twin engined plane to carry out the sortie. Temporary Lieutenant (A) [[Noel Ernest Goddard, RNVR]], at the time the Senior Pilot of 771 NAS, volunteered to pilot the sortie, with his crew of Acting Leading Airman [[John Walker Armstrong]] as TAG-WO, and Leading Airman [[J. D. Milne]] as TAG-AG. The extremely experienced observer Commander [[Geoffry Alexander Rotherham]], at the time the Air Stations [[Executive Officer|XO]], stepped up to act as Mission Commander. Goddard flew on instruments at low level over the sea, making landfall on target. Having identified that the ships had sailed already they attempted to radio their discovery back to [[RAF Coastal Command]]. However, they did not receive any reply. Rotherham decided to contact the Air Station directly on the Towed Target frequency and also fly directly to HMS Sparrowhawk's forward airfield, Sumburgh, where the Albacores were ready to intercept. Acting on Rotherhams's radio message, the [[Home Fleet]] were set to sea and engage the Bismarck and her escorts intercepting her at the [[last battle of the battleship Bismarck|Battle of the Denmark Straits]]. On 16 September 1941 [[The London Gazette]] reported the awarding of the following honours: Rotherham received the [[Distinguished Service Order|DSO]],http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/35275/supplements/5357/page.pdf Goddard the [[Distinguished Service Cross (United Kingdom)|DSC]],http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/35275/supplements/5358/page.pdf and Armstrong the [[Distinguished Service Medal (United Kingdom)|DSM]]. Goddard went on to Command 771 NAS as a Temporary Lieutenant Commander (A) on 15 October 1941. On 1 July 1942 771 NAS moved to [[Twatt, Orkney|RNAS Twatt]] to fly more modern aircraft in a similar role. ==Post Second World War== In February 1945, 771 received the [[Sikorsky R-4|Sikorsky Hoverfly]], making it the first naval air squadron to operate helicopters, which it used until May 1947. After [[VE Day|victory in Europe]] the Fleet moved from [[Scapa Flow]] to [[HMNB Portsmouth|Portsmouth]] and the anchorage at [[Portland Harbour|Portland]]. 771 NAS followed south to [[RNAS Zeals]] and then to [[RNAS Lee-on-Solent]] and [[RNAS Ford]]. Here the Squadron flew [[Miles Martinet]]s, [[Douglas A-20 Havoc|Douglas Bostons]], [[Vought F4U Corsair|Vought Corsairs]], [[Grumman Wildcat]]s, [[Airspeed Oxford]]s, [[Grumman Hellcat]]s, [[Supermarine Seafire]]s, [[North American T-6 Texan|North American Harvards]], [[de Havilland Mosquito]]es, [[Hawker Sea Fury]]s, [[Short Sturgeon]]s, as well as the [[Sikorsky R-4|Hoverfly]]. The Hoverflies were transferred to [[705 Naval Air Squadron]] as it was formed. During the Defence reductions following the Second World War it was decided that 771 would be disbanded in August 1955 (whilst operating the [[Avro Anson]], [[de Havilland Hornet|de Havilland Sea Hornet]], [[Gloster Meteor]], [[de Havilland Sea Vampire]] and [[Fairey Firefly]]) when it combined with [[703 Naval Air Squadron]] to form [[700 Naval Air Squadron]]. ==Helicopter-only squadron== 771 NAS reformed in 1961 and assumed the helicopter trials and training roles from 700 NAS with the [[Westland Whirlwind (helicopter)|Westland Whirlwind]], [[Westland Dragonfly]], and the [[Westland Wasp]] prototype at [[RNAS Portland (HMS Serepta, HMS Osprey)|RNAS Portland]]. During this time 771 was able to pioneer and develop many '''Search And Rescue''' techniques; including helicopter in-flight refueling ([[HIFR]]), hi-line transfer, free diver drop and cliff winching techniques. Soon after standing up again, the Squadron gained two Westland Whirlwind HAR.3s and assumed the RNAS Portland SAR commitment. The Squadron was disbanded on 1 December 1964, on being absorbed into [[829 Naval Air Squadron]]. [[Image:Westland Whirlwind HAS.7 XL878 PO-514 771 Sq Portl 200767 edited-2.jpg|thumb|right|771 Squadron [[Westland Whirlwind (helicopter)|Westland Whirlwind]] HAS.7 SAR rescue helicopter at Portland in 1967.]] On 23 June 1967, the squadron reformed with the new primary task of [[Anti-submarine warfare|anti-submarine warfare (ASW)]] Fleet Requirements Unit, in addition to the Portland SAR duty. Nine Whirlwind HAS.7 were used by the Squadron at this time. The [[Westland Wessex]] was introduced in 1969 with the Mk 1. This marked the beginning of a long association of the aircraft with the squadron. By 1970, the ASW role had been passed on to [[737 Naval Air Squadron]], making SAR 771's primary role, a role that has remained to the present day. The Squadron moved to [[RNAS Culdrose (HMS Seahawk)|RNAS Culdrose]] in September 1974. Six of its Wessex aircraft were left at RNAS Portland, to form the basis of [[772 Naval Air Squadron]]. The Wessex HAS.1 was replaced by the twin turbine-powered Wessex HU.5 in 1979, when it was involved with the [[1979 Fastnet race]] rescues. During the [[Falklands Conflict]] all of 771 aircraft were taken for troop transport roles, some went to 722 Naval Air Squadron, but the majority reformed [[847 Naval Air Squadron]] and [[848 Naval Air Squadron]] along with some of 771 NASs aircrew. The remaining crew went either to their old aircraft type, or to new roles in the [[Westland Lynx|Lynx]] or [[Westland Wasp|Wasp]] fleets. Two Wessex Mk.5 from Wroughton were used in August 1982 to form the backbone of 771 NAS as it took the SAR commitment back from the RAF. In January 1983 the Squadron once again operated mixed fleets of rotary and fixed wing aircraft as it absorbed the Station Flight, taking ownership of two [[de Havilland Chipmunk|Chipmunks]] and 2 [[de Havilland Dove|Sea Devons]]. It operated these until the end of 1989 when the Sea Devon was withdrawn from service. In 1985 the Squadron absorbed [[707 Naval Air Squadron]]'s Wessex helicopters when 771 NAS took over [[Commando]] Helicopter Training. The Wessex were replaced by [[Westland Sea King]] HAS.5s, converted to HAR.5s, in October 1987 as the Squadron assumed a long range, day/night and all weather SAR capability. In July 2001, 771 Squadron assumed the responsibility for Advanced and Operational Flying Training for anti-submarine warfare (ASW) pilots and Observers, as well as the residual Sea King HAS.5 & HAS.6 Pilot Conversion and Refresher Courses. [[File:050625-Kiel-x80-600.jpg|thumb]] In its final years the Squadron operated the Sea King HAR.5 in the grey and red colours, with nine permanently stationed at RNAS Culdrose. 771's sister unit, [[HMS Gannet SAR Flight|Gannet Flight]] operates 3 HAR.5s performing a similar role from HMS Gannet on [[Prestwick Airport]]. 771's primary role was one of military Search and Rescue, with secondary roles in civilian Search and Rescue, Pilot and Observer refresher training, utility and liaison and ab-initio Pilot Conversion and operational training. To perform these roles, one of the helicopters was on 15 minutes notice to fly during the day, and 45 minutes during the night, with a duty crew on call for 24 hours. This duty was maintained for 365 days of the year, with a second standby aircraft ready to assist should the emergency have demanded it. It stopped rescue duties on 1 January 2016 and was decommissioned on 22 March 2016. The squadron was responsible for saving over 15,000 lives on more than 9,000 missions.http://www.plymouthherald.co.uk/Final-shift-Cornwall-based-rescue-crew-771-Naval/story-28445365-detail/story.html{{cite web|last1=Graeme|first1=W B|title=Final ceremony disbands navy 771 search and rescue squadron at RNAS Culdrose Helston|url=http://www.cornishman.co.uk/Final-ceremony-disbands-navy-771-search-rescue/story-28971195-detail/story.html|website=The Cornishman|accessdate=22 March 2016}} ==Ace of Clubs== 771s Helicopters feature the unofficial Ace of Clubs Squadron Logo. The origin of this logo is unclear, but it is widely believed to follow a similar pedigree as the [[Royal Navy Historic Flight]] [[Hawker Sea Hawk]], wearing 806 NAS's Ace of Diamonds logo. Shortly after the Second World War Squadrons of the Fleet Air Arm often had an in-house display team. Each of the display aircraft were painted with identification marks. Playing card suits were chosen by some Squadrons as they were a neat identification that allows clear hierarchy; the Squadron Commanding Officer would take the Ace card, the XO the King and so on until each aircraft had a value relating to the seniority in the Squadron/display team of that pilot. Today 771 does not assign an aircraft to each pilot, instead operating a pool of aircraft allowing each pilot to fly any helicopter. It was chosen that only the Ace of Clubs would be painted on each of the helicopters in the Squadrons fleet. ==Rescues== 771 NAS is one of the busiest SAR units in the UK being called out an average of 220 times per year. With the limitations in civilian flight rules for the Cornwall Air Ambulance pilots 771 is also often called upon to perform patient and hospital transfers throughout the West Country. These are typically when the Air Ambulance is engaged in other duties, in poor weather, at night or where no suitable landing place is close by, allowing the [[Westland Sea King|Sea King]] to utilise its winch. Individual honours have included 4 [[George Medal]]s, 3 [[Air Force Cross (United Kingdom)|Air Force Crosses]], 6 [[Queen's Gallantry Medal|Queens Gallantry Medals]], and 14 [[Queen's Commendation for Bravery]] awards. Some of the more memorable rescues have been: * 1978 – [[Ben Asdale]], '''Air Force Cross''' awarded to Lt [[Tony Hogg|AJM Hogg]] RN, and Lt Cdr MJ Norman RN{{cite web|url=http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/47950/supplements/11475 |title=Viewing Page 11475 of Issue 47950 |publisher=London-gazette.co.uk |date=1979-09-10 |accessdate=2012-07-09}} * 1979 – [[1979 Fastnet race|Fastnet Race]]http://www.blur.se/images/fastnet-race-inquiry.pdf * 1985 – [[Fastnet Race]], '''George Medal''' awarded to the Rescue Diver; POACMN L Slater{{cite web|url=http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/50453/supplements/3447 |title=Viewing Page 3447 of Issue 50453 |publisher=London-gazette.co.uk |date=1986-03-10 |accessdate=2012-07-09}} for his rescue of [[Simon Le Bon]] and 19 other survivors from the Yacht ''Drum'' * 1985 – [[Yacht Master Cube]] * 1989 – [[MV Secil Japan]],http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/52024/pages/969/page.pdf '''Air Force Medal''' awarded to the Rescue Diver CPOACMN JPR Grinney{{cite web|url=http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/52024/pages/1 |title=Viewing Page 969 of Issue 52024 |publisher=London-gazette.co.uk |date=1990-01-22 |accessdate=2012-07-09}} * 1989 – [[MV Murree]],{{cite web|url=http://www.shipspotting.com/gallery/photo.php?lid=1300606 |title=MURREE – IMO 8000161 – ShipSpotting.com – Ship Photos and Ship Tracker |publisher=ShipSpotting.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-09}} '''George Medal''' awarded to each of the 2 Rescue Divers; POACMN DS Wallace, POACMN SW Wright http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/52218/supplements/12275/page.pdf * 1992 – [[Boyd Trophy]] won for night rescue of five crew from yacht Sine Seorra off Guernsey, '''Air Force Medal''' awarded to LA I Chambershttp://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/53255/supplements/5191/page.pdf * 2004 – [[Boyd Trophy]] won for [[Boscastle flood of 2004|Boscastle Flood]] rescues,{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/cornwall/4287436.stm |title=UK | England | Cornwall | Bravery awards for flood heroes |publisher=BBC News |date=2005-09-27 |accessdate=2012-07-09}} '''Air Force Cross''' awarded to Lt Cdr MJ Ford RN{{cite web|url=https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/57588/supplement/3379/data.htm |title=Page 3379, Supplement 57588, 18 March 2005, London Gazette|publisher=London-gazette.co.uk |date=2005-03-18 |accessdate=2015-04-12}} * 2005 – [[Boyd Trophy]] won for the recovery of critically ill crewman from fishing vessel 240 miles off coast in gale force winds and very poor visibility * 2007 – [[MSC Napoli]], PO J O'Donnel awarded '''Queen's Gallantry Medal''' * 2008 – Pesca del Verdes, CPOACMN D Rigg awarded '''Queen's Gallantry Medal'''{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/cornwall/8411870.stm | work=BBC News | title=Rescue winchman gets royal award | date=14 December 2009}} * 2009 – Fishing Vessel Trevessa, PO D Lacy awarded '''Queen's Gallantry Medal'''http://www.thisiscornwall.co.uk/Fishermen-rescued-trawler-blaze/story-11393293-detail/story.html#axzz2RCNfPJ8U * 2011 – Yacht Andriette, Sgt A Russell RM awarded '''George Medal''' for his role in the rescue{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2299022/Royal-Marine-helicopter-winchman-rescued-men-stranded-yacht-worst-weather-s-seen-awarded-George-Medal.html | location=London | work=Daily Mail | first=Olivia | last=Williams | title=Royal Marine helicopter winchman who rescued two men from a stranded yacht in 'worst weather he's ever seen' is awarded the George Medal | date=25 March 2013}} ==RN SAR 60== As one of only two presently commissioned units of the ten that have operated in the dedicated Royal Navy Search and Rescue role, 771 NAS are a core part of the year-long celebration to recognise [[Royal Navy SAR 60|60 years of RN Helicopter Search and Rescue]]. Events are taking place throughout the country and media all year, with the RN SAR Force raising £60,000 for charity. [[File:Royal Navy Search and Rescue 60 Logo.png|thumb|149x149px]] ==Aircraft Operated by 771 NAS== There are 68 different marks of aircraft known to have been operated by 771 NAS.
